question_text: What type of muscle biopsy finding is associated with Kearns-Sayre Syndrome?

options.A: Necrotizing myopathy
options.B: Ragged-red fibers on Gomori trichrome stain

options.A: patient diagnosed with breast cancer underwent chemotherapy and radiation. An EMG showed myokymia and the patient presented with plexopathy. What is your diagnosis?

question_text: Peripheral neuropathy case: what is the antibody?

options.A: Anti MAG
young man (or child) has muscle stiffness that improves with repeated exercise (myotonia and warm-up phenomena). His father had the same symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: In a patient with painful diabetic neuropathy who is nonambulatory and has severe spasticity, which treatment is most likely to provide relief?

options.A: Addition of benzodiazepines
patient presents with generalized weakness, bilateral ptosis, respiratory involvement, and areflexia. What additional finding would you expect?
young lady presents with weakness in knee extension and numbness in the medial aspect of the thigh. Which lower limb nerve is likely affected?

patient presents with bilateral foot drop and left ulnar neuropathy with abductor digiti minimi weakness, progressive over 3 months. Nerve conduction studies showed conduction block in the ulnar nerve and deep peroneal nerve at the head of the fibula. What is the diagnosis?

He was admitted to the hospital with high creatine kinase (CK) levels. Upon review of his chart, it was noted that he was admitted last year with the same presentation. What is the defective enzyme?

question_text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Kearns-Sayre Syndrome (KSS)?

options.A: Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO)
patient with myasthenia gravis and thymus hyperplasia is on pyridostigmine and is experiencing worsening generalized weakness. What is the recommended next step in management?

question_text: Typical scenario of Myasthenia Gravis in a young lady with fluctuating ptosis. What is the best serological test in this case?

options.A: Single fiber EMG
C8-T1

question_text: In hyperkalemic periodic paralysis, which of the following is a characteristic feature?

options.A: Usually mild paralysis

question_text: When should Guillain-Barré syndrome be suspected?

options.A: Rapidly progressive bilateral limb weakness

question_text: In a scenario of Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP) on day 5, what will the nerve conduction study (NCS) show?

options.A: Sural sparing with affected median and ulnar nerves
options.B: Normal sensory and motor nerve conduction velocities
options.C: Increased amplitude of compound muscle action potentials
options.D: Early recruitment of motor units on electromyography

options.A: patient came with right upper limb weakness and intrinsic hand atrophy with diminished reflexes. What is the diagnosis?
typical case of Hirayama disease presents with right upper limb weakness with preserved brachioradialis and minimal weakness in the left upper limb. What is the associated finding in this patient?

question_text: Which condition is characterized by myotonia that worsens with exercise?

options.A: Paramyotonia congenita

question_text: Which of the following may be elevated in patients with Kearns-Sayre Syndrome?

options.A: Serum creatine kinase (CK)
case about ulnar nerve injury presents with claw hand. What is the likely diagnosis?
pregnant lady presents with hyperemesis gravidarum and sensory disturbances in her distal limbs. What is the likely cause?

question_text: An elderly patient with volar hand weakness may be suspected of having which condition?

options.A: Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM)
